newsitem.title: CHINA: China stocks down sharply on clampdown fears.
newsitem.headline: China stocks down sharply on clampdown fears.

text.p: China's A and B share indices ended sharply down on Thursday as rumours swirled through the markets about possible official measures to cool down trading, brokers said.
The Shanghai B index tumbled 4.871 points or 4.96 percent to 93.335 while the Shenzhen B index fell 6.13 points or 3.35 percent to 176.61.

Two local brokers in Shanghai said that if Beijing came out with serious measures to rein in the markets, the A share indices could fall up to 15 or 20 percent in the short-term, given the speed of the rises in recent months.
But many brokers expressed scepticism about Beijing planning anything major with the Hong Kong handover now so close.

"There is no way they'd do anything serious at this point," said John Crossman, general manager of Jardine Fleming in Shanghai. "Everything has got to be smooth sailing through the Hong Kong handover (on June 30)."
"Beijing doesn't want to see any dramatic movements either up or down before the handover," said a broker in Shenzhen. "I don't expect anything drastic to be announced."

China's official newspapers are continuing to publish articles warning of risks in the stock markets and a leading economist was quoted on Thursday as saying the time had come to list currently non-tradeable state and institutional shares.
A Hong Kong newspaper also said China's Ministry of Finance was considering increasing stamp duties for trading stocks from the current 0.3 percent to 0.4 or 0.5 percent.
"Beijing will not tolerate the abnormally high domestic A share prices, and rumours circulating in the market say clampdown measures will be worked out soon," said one local broker.
"If there is a crackdown, I would say the A market could fall 15 or 20 percent, and would then consolidate for a while," said another broker.
Shanghai Worldbest was the biggest loser in Shanghai, slumping $0.07 or 9.33 percent to $0.68.
The market barometer Shanghai Lujiazui Finance & Trade Zone Development was the most actively traded, down $0.108 or 6.67 percent to $1.51 on volume of 3.6 million shares.
"Investor jitters over recent strong A share gains affected the B share market," an analyst at J&A Securities said.
In Shenzhen, upcoming B share offers drained some funds from the B share market, analysts said.

Pesticide maker Hubei Sanonda Co Ltd, Shandong Chenming Paper Holdings Ltd and Nanjing Posts & Telecommunications Equipment Co Ltd will each offer 100 million B shares for listing in Shenzhen this month.
But analysts said they expected the three new stocks to perform well on their listing debuts, which will likely boost investor sentiment.
Most analysts said they were confident that the underlying trend remained bullish.
The Shanghai A index slipped 94.789 points or 6.07 percent to 1,467.861 on turnover of 15.4 billion yuan. The SSE30 blue chip index fell 320.921 points or 7.27 percent to 4,092.126.

The Shenzhen A share index plunged 31.87 points or 5.97 percent to end at 501.92 on turnover of 20.2 billion yuan, following a record high close of 533.78 points on Wednesday on turnover of 21.3 billion yuan.
